column1: Incheon (Korean: 인천; Hanja: 仁川; Korean pronunciation: [intɕʰʌn]; McCune-Reischauer romanization Inchŏn; literally "kind river")
column3: is a city located in northwestern South Korea
column4: bordering Seoul and Gyeonggi to the east. Inhabited since the Neolithic
column6: 700 people when it became an international port in 1883. Today
column7: about 3 million people live in the city
column8: making it South Korea's third most-populous city after Seoul and Busan.

column1: The city's growth has been assured in modern times with the development of its port due to its natural advantages as a coastal city and its proximity to the South Korean capital. It is part of the Seoul Capital Area
column2: along with Seoul itself and Gyeonggi Province
column3: forming the world's fourth largest metropolitan area by population.

column1: Incheon has since led the economic development of Korea by opening its port to the outside world
column2: ushering in the modernization of Korea as a center of industrialization. In 2003
column3: the city was designated as Korea's first free economic zone. Since then
column4: large local companies and global enterprises have increasingly invested in the Incheon Free Economic Zone

column2: Incheon has held numerous large scale international conferences

Incheon has established itself as a major transportation hub in northeast Asia with the Incheon International Airport and Incheon Port. The city is also home to the Green Climate Fund
column4: an international organization addressing environmental issues.

column1: Incheon was known as Inchon prior to South Korea's adoption of a new Romanization system in 2000.
The city was the site of the Battle of Chemulpo Bay
column2: where the first shots of the Russo-Japanese War were fired.
Incheon was occupied by North Korean troops on 4 September 1950. Eleven days later
column3: Incheon was the site of the Battle of Inchon
column4: when United States troops landed to relieve pressure on the Pusan Perimeter and to launch a United Nations offensive northward. The result was a decisive UN victory and it was recaptured on 19 September 1950. The USS Inchon was named after the tide-turning battle that ensued.

column1: Incheon has also hosted a series of major international events. The Global Fair & Festival 2009 Incheon was held in the Songdo District in August 2009.  It was open from 7 August to 25 October for a period of 80 days. It was a comprehensive international event with global institutions and corporations as participants. Various musicians and artists performed during the event.
The city hosted a meeting of the G20 Finance Ministers in February 2010. Incheon was the site of the third Global Model United Nations Conference
column2: held from 10th to the 14th of August 2011.

column1: Many BRT lines offer transportation between Seoul and Incheon.

column4: Uijeongbu and Soyosan is offered by Seoul's subway Line 1. The line has 11 stations within Incheon and connects to the Incheon Subway at Bupyeong and Juan stations.

column1: Rapid service on the same line to Yongsan Station in Seoul depart from Dongincheon station and stops at major stations.

The Airport Express (AREX) line runs from Incheon International Airport to Seoul Station via Gimpo International Airport. The Incheon-Gimpo section was opened in March 2007 and was extended to Seoul station in December 2010. Passengers can choose a high-speed service stopping only at Incheon airport and Seoul
column2: which takes 43 minutes but departs only every half-hour; or the all-station service which takes 53 minutes but leaves every six minutes.

column1: KTX service was introduced on the AREX line on 30 June 2014
column2: with stops at Incheon International Airport Station and Geoman Station. There are additional plans to use the newly built Suin Line to bring KTX service to Incheon Station by 2021.

column1: The Incheon Subway has two subway lines serving the city. The first line connects to the Seoul Metropolitan Subway system at Bupyeong Station (Seoul Subway Line 1)
column2: and AREX line at Gyeyang Station. It connects International Business District Station in Songdo to Gyeyang Station. The line has 28 stations on 29.4 kilometres (18.3 miles) of track. The line also has transfer stations with the Suin Line at Woninjae Station
column3: with the Incheon Subway Line 2 at Incheon City Hall Station
column4: and with Seoul Subway Line 7 at Bupyeong-gu Office Station. Incheon Subway Line 2 opened in July 2016 and runs from Geomdan Oryu Station to Unyeon Station. The automated line is 29.2 kilometres (18.1 miles) long
